title: Frame & Chassis Assembly
description: Assemble the main frame and chassis components that form the structural foundation of the golf cart.

steps.title: Frame Preparation & Inspection
steps.instructions: Inspect the main frame for shipping damage, cracks, or defects. Check all mounting points and holes for proper alignment. Clean any protective coating or debris from welding surfaces.

safetyWarnings.text: Frame components are heavy. Use proper lifting techniques or lifting equipment.

commonMistakes: Not checking for cracks in weld zones
steps.whyItMatters: A damaged frame cannot be repaired and will compromise the entire cart's structural integrity.

steps.title: Install Front Suspension Mounts
steps.instructions: Attach the front suspension mounting brackets to the frame. Torque all bolts to 45 ft-lbs in a star pattern. Verify brackets are level and square to frame.

safetyWarnings.text: Under-torqued suspension bolts can fail during operation causing loss of control.

steps.whyItMatters: Suspension mounts carry all steering and handling loads. Proper installation is critical for safety.

steps.title: Rear Axle Installation
steps.instructions: Install the rear axle assembly into frame mounts. Ensure bearings are properly seated. Torque axle mounting bolts to 65 ft-lbs. Check for free rotation.

safetyWarnings.text: Support axle assembly properly during installation. Dropped axles can cause serious injury.

steps.whyItMatters: The rear axle transmits all power to the wheels. Improper installation causes premature bearing failure.

knowledgeChecks.question: What is the correct torque specification for front suspension mounting bolts?
knowledgeChecks.explanation: Front suspension mounts require 45 ft-lbs torque in a star pattern to ensure even clamping force.

knowledgeChecks.question: Why is it important to inspect the frame before assembly?
options: It's not important, just a formality
To find shipping damage or defects that could compromise safety
knowledgeChecks.explanation: Frame inspection catches damage that would compromise structural integrity. A damaged frame cannot be repaired.
